comments.commentBody: " College Savings 529 Plans, used by many middle class families who work and save for college". - I wonder how many of these plans have equally been the victims of for profit scams ? What are the recourses if they are?

You have absolutely no idea what you are writing about.  Analysis of the 529 plans showed they were used overwhelmingly by the wealthy for tax avoidance purposes, just like the home interest deduction.  Obama strengthened the public service loan forgiveness program and created an income-based repayment option that is 10% of adjusted-gross income.  This has help tremendously my wife and I who work in public higher education.  My is a licensed speech pathologist who used to work for a non-profit hospital and started school before Obama was president.  She has to pay 15% on her loans; I pay 10%.  Given the paltry salaries of most rank-and-file higher education employees (contrary to popular misconception), this is a life-altering help.  I do not know what better example you want of pre-Obama post-Obama than the 10%-15%.  What's more, this is a research interest of mine and Obama has gone after for-profits with gainful employment rules, college scorecard, proposed rating system, Warren's financial consumer protection agency; in short, everything he can think of to go around their powerful allies in congress who block reform at the expense of everyone but the 1%.

But my point is not that people who are financially strapped should not get help.  My point is that the way to help them should not involve punishing those who work and save to afford college.  The Obama administration has tried to help the lower quartile by taking from the second quartile.  It's actually been a lazy, not heroic, strategy.  Lazy because taking away tax incentivized savings plans like the 529 is just low-lying fruit held by the middle class, not structural change that requires much more effort and risk.  Rather than proposing taking away the 529s, why didn't the Obama administration lower the interest rates on Federal student loans? Why didn't they cap tuition increases on public universities that receive major Federal aid in the form of grants?  Why didn't they do ANYTHING to stem the escalation of college costs?  No. Instead they tried to strip one of the few vehicles available to those who CAN save. It's a hostile approach to the middle and upper-middle class, rather than a sophisticated approach to a broad problem with widespread casualties.

The Obama administration has been all over the map when it comes to higher education.  What has been consistent, though, is a greater concern for students from poor backgrounds and a hostility towards those from hardworking middle class backgrounds.  For example, the Obama administration has implemented a plan to forgive the loans of low income students who are unable to pay them back, while at the same time proposing to get rid of the College Savings 529 Plans, used by many middle class families who work and save for college.  Over and over again, this administration has tried to bail out the working poor at the expense to the middle class, leaving Wall Street, and the 1 percent, quite untouched.  As a third generation Democrat, I have never been more alienated from a Democratic administration as I am from this one.  When it comes to college costs, the answer regarding how to help students from poor families is not to punish those from middle class families who have struggled to get where they are.

A state prison could say the exact same thing with the same level of honesty. You will learn all kinds of nonsense in a state prison you can't learn outside.
The big difference is that like legitimate state university systems and colleges that are highly respected degree granting institutions, a state prison won't make you pay absurdly high rates for the cells, nor charge you for really bad food.

agreed. Republicans support privation of everything because this is the only they can think of for job creation and they fail to get to the root problem. Of our beleaguered economy one of which is supporting things like this.
Couldn't have said it any better!

Capitalism works when you are selling cars, computers or cruise vacations but not for life,death and education.
Requiring voting will certainly not promote better outcomes. The votes of uninterested, uninformed, unconcerned citizens added to the mix, is not an especially attractive proposition.
I cannot stop laughing.  At the article, the people in it, the story itself, and the reactions.  This is hilarious.

The version of the Constitution that was approved by the South in 1860-61 - removing the interstate commerce clause - was a major statement against the federal power to interfere in the affairs of states.

I have been a student of the civil war period for a long time and never heard anyone ''out there'' far enough to pitch return of runaways as a state's rights issue for the North. Perhaps we can blame the Dred Scott decision as our gateway to the destruction of state authority.

I suppose you could see the ''sanctuary cities'' scheme as a modern-day politically-correct proclamation that the states now make to recover lost authority.
I liked the ending, where we learned that in Manchester 'enery is spelt wif a Haitch.
He was a little before my time.  His girlfriend was like Miss Kitty, only more so.  That's about what I remember.

Come on, Bill.
You bought the annual Pigskin Preseason issue because it also contained "Girls of the ACC," "Girls of the Pac 12," etc.

In all seriousness, Playboy should improve its sports pre-season previews.  There was a time when we all read those previews, but over time they became progressively poorer.  Even after I had stopped buying the magazine, I always bought the issue with the football preview.  Unfortunately -- as sports radio inadvertently made clear -- the pre-season previews were often superficial and filled with mis-information.
That will make them a clone of Esquire magazine.  Good luck with that.

So it is nearly impossible in fact to get convictions even though the law can be read as reasonable by those who want to read it that way.  Such a situation seems to be standard in large parts of our jurisprudence.

Please define what you mean by government benefits.

Arguably the Koch Brothers and the oil and gas industry have received the most government benefit.
So does this mean my December 1953 issue will be worth More than 6,500 ?
It pretty much is...
So did I!
Pheww.  When I first saw the picture of Hef, I thought it was an obituary.

Well, as an artist who's body sculptures were featured in Playboy June 1977, Beautiful Bod, it was a thrill.  The magazine for my generation was a vehicle of not just gorgeous females in sexy attire but more of a sounding board for deeper political, artistic, fashion oriented and yes, technological gadgets (see my non-electronic breast work and digital thigh band).  What's interesting is that Playboy's photo editor saw the works they invited me to Chicago. Later my works were shown to Spielberg's group prior to Princess Lelia's debut  but the designs were not chosen for the film. None the less I acknowledged Playboy as an artistic publication and laud them for their new ideas presenting artist's with a format for discovery. Thank you and much future success on your new endeavor!  I have a complete collection of original oils I'd like to show you with body sculptures I've designed and created!
In  other news, Ford Motor Company has suspended production of its popular Model T.

Venerable, really! I think not.
How many women began hating their own bodies when they saw, or found their man with, a copy of Playboy? Good riddance.

How many young guys saw their first naked hottie, photographed artfully on these pages?  It was a nearly religious experience.  Yeah, the magazine is intelligent and well-written, but Playboy set the standard for nude female beauty for decades.  Another venerable American institution is lost to posterity.

No, Playboy is NOT pornographic.  Nothing "graphic" about it at all.  Simple and tasteful.  The author oddly doesn't understand that.  This is sad news, and ultimately the nail in the coffin for the company.

I'm a highly educated millenial male urbanite and I think this is a spectacularly bad decision.   It shows a complete disconnect with their core brand and audience while also doing away with convention out of patent desperation.  They will not gain and long term readership or brand engagement, but they will manage to lose an important segment of their customer base.

To all of those sounding the death knell for Playboy, might I hazard a guess that you are "of a certain age"? Frankly, Playboy doesn't want you anymore. It can't survive with your readership anymore. Its only choice is to target to the younger male, one to whom Playboy in its current incarnation is a quaint anachronism. It is an open question if they will be able to pull it off.

What's that you say? Do you really mean to suggest that Playboy Magazine is still in print?

Who knew?
wish you were around when my mom caught me with a copy, in India, I might add.
The abundance of internet porn would suggest you're mistaken.

Huh? I do not believe you are living in reality. As far as I've read, porn websites are by far the most frequently visited and have proliferated greatly. And are presumably visited by men (and boys) who are most definitely interested in seeing nude women.

Maybe your comment was meant to be ironic.

Incisive articles and a good layout are necessary for any hope of success on the internet.  The current Playboy website doesn't cut it (it's all bubble gum).  If Playboy doesn't pull things together they will go the way of RadioShack (where we all bought our first tape recorders).
So finally, all of the protestations that "I buy it for the articles," become true.
